Centering activity - Setting the stage - Paired coding - Group Debrief ## Centering Activity * Reena :-) ## Exit Ticket Results {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](06-assess_braceros_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Setting the Stage - This week's focus is on data tidying and transformation - Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped - Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program ## Learning Outcomes - Understand data structure - Transform and tidy data for necessary questions - Explore and summarize patterns - Connect your findings to theoretical understandings of procedural justice ## Let's get Started - Find your pair - Open Posit ## First Steps - Import Data - Load packages - You may need to install readxl using `install.packages("package name")`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readxl) # for loading data library(tidyverse) # for tidying ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # | eval: true # | echo: false bracero <- read_excel("~/Google Drive/My Drive/Teaching/ES-202/Case Study Code/data/week_03/bracero_pull.xlsx") ``` ::: ## Load Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero <- read_excel("data/bracero_pull.xlsx") ``` ::: ## Our data {.smaller} - 90 rows (interviews) - 6 variables (all `chr` type) - title = Person interviewed - subject = topic of interview - description = summary of interview - date = date of interview - identifier = link to original interview file - language = language interview was conducted in ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(bracero) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Variable Types {.smaller} We will work primarily with five types of variables in this course: - `chr` is character - `dbl` is double (number) - `int` is an integer - `date` is date - `fct` is factor Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Transforming Data (Columns) {.smaller} - Four functions can change the *columns* of your data without affecting your *rows* - mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones - select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe - rename(): changes the names of current columns - relocate(): changes the position of those columns ## mutate() function {.smaller} - mutate() creates new columns based on existing ones - We use the `mutate()` function to create a new column `year`, using the `year()` function to change the original `date` column to include only the year, formatted as a date. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero <- bracero |> mutate(year = year(date)) ``` ::: ## mutate() function (cont.) {.smaller} - We can also pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements. - `%in%c()` allows you to list multiple matches in the `subject` column. ![](images/ifelse.png) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(subject_binary = ifelse(subject %in%c("bracero", "Bracero"), "Bracero", "Non-bracero")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 8 title subject description date identifier language year subject_binary 1 Richard H‚Ä¶ Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003 Non-bracero 2 Pedro Can‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 Bracero 3 Asterio L‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2006 Bracero 4 Vincente ‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 Bracero 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003 Non-bracero 6 Manuel En‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2003 Non-bracero 7 Alberto M‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 Bracero 8 Ernesto E‚Ä¶ Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2005 Non-bracero 9 Jes√∫s Ort‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 Bracero 10 Jos√© G. C‚Ä¶ Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 Non-bracero # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## select() function {.smaller} - `select()` can be used to select or deselect columns. - Perhaps we'd like to remove the original `date` column from our dataframe. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3|7|11"} # select column you don't want bracero |> select(-date) # select columns you do want bracero |> select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, year) # select columns in a row, except the column you don't want bracero |> select(title:description, identifier:year) ``` ::: ## rename() function {.smaller} - `rename()` changes the names of current columns - let's rename `title` to something more descriptive like `interviewee`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> rename("interviewee" = "title") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 interviewee subject description date identifier language year 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a An‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2006 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 5 Inez Rios Interac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2003 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 8 Ernesto Espino Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2005 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005 # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## relocate() function {.smaller} - `relocate()` changes the position of columns - `relocate()` automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify the column's location, and `.after` or `.before`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> relocate(identifier, .after = language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date language identifier year 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a An‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2003 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2006 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 5 Inez Rios Interac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2003 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2003 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 8 Ernesto Espino Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 2005 # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Put it together {.smaller} - We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the `|>` function - line 1: creates new dataframe called `bracero_clean` - line 2: creates formatted year column called `year` from the original `date` column. - line 3: selects for all columns *except* for the old `date` column - line 4: renames the `title` column to `interviewee` - line 5: moves the `indentifier` column to after the `year` column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2|3|4|5"} bracero_clean <- bracero |> mutate(year = year(date)) |> select(-date) |> rename("interviewee" = "title") |> relocate(identifier, .after = year) ``` ::: # Exercise One {.smaller} - Starting with the `bracero` dataframe, code the following three actions using into a new dataframe called `bracero_ex1` - mutate the `date` column into a new column, called `year` using the `year()` function. - select the `title`, `year`, and `description` columns. - relocate the `year` column to be the first in the dataframe. # Transforming Data (Rows) - Moving on to rows! - `filter()` is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won't change the order of your rows) - `arrange()` changes the order of your rows (but won't filter for anything) ## filter() function {.smaller} - Use the `filter()` function to select rows that correspond to values of interest. - use `==` to filter the `language` column for rows with a direct match (in this case `spa`) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(language == "spa") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 75 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language year identifier 1 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Eduardo De Santiago Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Salvador Torres Beltr√°n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 65 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## filter() operations {.smaller} - `>` greater than - `>=` greater than or equal to - `<` less than - `<=` less than or equal to - `==` equal to - `!=` does not equal - Can use `&` to combine conditions (and) - `|` to select multiple conditions (or) - Perhaps we're interested in interviews that took place after 2004 AND are in English: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(year >= 2004 & language == "eng") ``` ::: ## filter() and str_detect() {.smaller} - We can also combine filter with the `str_detect()` function, to look for character matches in a column (in this case the `interviewee` column, with any matches including `Alberto` . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language year identifier 1 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographical Syno‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Alberto Magall√≥n Jim√©nez Bracero "Biographical Syno‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Alberto Mendoza Torres bracero "Biographical Syno‚Ä¶ spa 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## arrange() - `arrange()` sorts your rows based on the values in the columns. - If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to "break ties" - including `desc()` will sort your column values big to small. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> arrange(desc(year, interviewee)) ``` ::: ## Exercise Two {.smaller} 1. Filter the `bracero_ex_1` dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 (using the `year` column) with an interviewee whose name includes ‚ÄúGuadalupe‚Äù. 2. Arrange the `bracero_ex1` data frame in descending order by `year`. What was the year, how many interviews took place in that year, and who is listed first? 3. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any description columns that mention "California". How many interviewees are there? # Grouping Data ## group_by() function {.smaller} - `group_by()` function is really helpful for sorting your data into groups for analysis. - `group_by()` function does not change your data, but *will change* subsequent operations if you use them in tandem with a `group_by()` - You can also group by multiple columns. In this case, I've grouped by both `year` and `language` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(year, language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 # Groups: year, language [6] interviewee subject description language year identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## summarize() - `summarize()` is often used in tandem with the `group_by()` function to calculate summary statistic(s) for a group. - In this case we are grouping the `bracero_clean` dataframe by the values in the `language` column, and summarizing the number of interviews using the `n()` function in a new column called `n_interviews`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) |> summarize(n_interviews = n()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 2 language n_interviews 1 eng 15 2 spa 75 ``` ::: ::: ## Other summarize functions - You can summarize values across groups using other functions, such as: - median() = median - mean() = average - sum() = sum ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) |> summarize(avg_date = mean(year)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 2 language avg_date 1 eng 2004. 2 spa 2004. ``` ::: ::: ## slice {.smaller} - `slice_` functions help select a subset of rows - slice_head(n = 5) will take the first five rows of the data - slice_tail(n = 5) will take the last five rows of the data - slice_min(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the lowest values for column x. - slice_max(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the highest values for column x. - slice_sample(n = 5) will select 5 random rows of data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> slice_min(year, n = 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 8 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language year identifier 1 Heriberto Cort√©z Cort√©z Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Gregorio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 H√©ctor Sol√≠s Fuentes Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Homero L√≥pez Ortiz Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Patricio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Liborio Santiago P√©rez Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Herminio Quezada Dur√°n Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Rodolfo Cruz Figueroa Bracero "Biographical Synop‚Ä¶ spa 2002 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Exercises Three and Four {.smaller} -
